Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Novel Natural Antioxidants Extracted from Animal Blood
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates the development of a natural antioxidant to be used as a food preservative. Natural antioxidants currently available on the market are usually obtained from plant sources, via extraction or a similar procedure. For instance, natural tocopherols (vitamin E) are refined from vegetable oils such as soybean oil. Other common natural antioxidants used in food industry such as rosemary oil extract are also isolated from plant sources. Extraction and purification procedures for these processes are time consuming and expensive, leading to high price of natural antioxidants. Much less attention has been paid thus far to natural antioxidants extracted from animal tissues. Animal or poultry blood could be of special interest as a potential source of natural antioxidants because of its low cost and broad availability. In addition, erythrocytes present in blood are equipped with an extremely efficient antioxidant "machinery" to protect the cell from continuous exposure to high levels of oxygen. Availability of potent antioxidant activity in erythrocytes prompted us to look into feasibility of commercially viable isolation of antioxidants from these cells. This project has the potential to further advance methods of extraction and characterization of antioxidants from animal/poultry blood and provide better insight on their safety and susceptibility to bacterial contamination. This could also advance knowledge about performance and stability of antioxidants extracted in partially purified form, in a mixture with other blood components.

Application of antioxidants increases the shelf life of food products and helps to maintain their healthiness, taste and nutritional value, whether it is used for preservation of animal or human food. The antioxidant developed through this project is a "green" product and responsive to society's demand for naturally derived products and will provide a cost-efficient way to address this demand. Even more broadly, this antioxidant can be used in any products where lipid oxidation has a negative effect on the product quality (e.g., as a preservative human food, and as antioxidant in varnishes, latexes, oil paints, etc.), which can provide markets for this product and further stimulate economic development.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview. Antioxidants are added to animal and human food to prevent rancidity. Natural antioxidants are strongly preferred by consumers. In response to the industry needs, we developed a proprietary method for extraction of natural, safe, and effective antioxidants from animal blood, which is broadly available as a co-product of animal processing plants. We have shown these novel antioxidants are as efficient as synthetic antioxidants in a number of relevant food models. Perhaps even more compelling is the low cost of production, which is several times cheaper than that for most of synthetic competitors, and 25-50 times cheaper than that for natural antioxidants. Major goal of this NSF I-CORPs project was to perform entrepreneural training for our team and do customer development interviews to make a "Go" or "No Go" decision. The secondary goal was to perfrom experiments to collect additional data on the efficacy of our product and its susceptibility to microbiological contamination.

Intelectual Merit. During the training period our team performed 138 customer development interviews with the following groups of potential customers: animal by-product renderers, pet food manufacturers, butcheries, meat shops at grocery stores, frozen meat manufacturers. These interviews helped us to validate our value proposition: cheaper and more efficient natural antioxidants. Also we were able to identify two groups of customers who were extremely intersted in our product. 100% of animal byproduct renderers and 94% of pet food manufacturers we interviewed told us they are excited about our product because current natural solutions are expensive and not sufficiently efficient. Furthermore, we identified an additional opportunity for a second generation product: human food applications in a frozen meat market. Our decision in the end of the training period was "Go". 

For the secondary goal, we successfully collected data for regulatory submission. As a result, new AAFCO animal feed ingredient definition petition was submitted in December 2014 and is currently pending consideration.

Overall, our business idea appears to be appealing for both customers and investors. This is evidenced by the interest from investors, media coverage of the company and the technology, and awards (of which most notable is the 2014 Innovision Award in the Samll Enterprise category). 

Broader Impacts. There are several ways in which introduction of our product will satisfy broader public interest. First, as any other antioxidant, its application will increase the shelf life of food products and help to maintain their healthiness, taste and nutritional value. Second, it is a  “green” product responsive to society’s demand for naturally derived products and will provide   cost-efficient way to address this demand. Third, commercialization of this product and construction of manufacturing facilities in agricultural sector will stimulate economic development and create new jobs in South Carolina (an EPSCORe state) and beyond.  Even more broadly, our product can be used in any area where lipid oxidation has a negative effect on quality. Hence, this product has a broader range of applications (e.g., second-generation product could be a preservative in human food, other potential uses include protection of cosmetics, fragrances, latexes and oil paints, etc., from oxidation). These applications can provide additional markets for our product and further stimulate economic development.


Last Modified: 04/01/2015
Modified by: Alexey A Vertegel
